page.title: 01GENERAL DESCRIPTION
page.content: WHITSOME LIES IN THE HIGHEST PART OF THE RIDGE BETWEEN THE RIVERS BLACKADDER, WHITEADDER AND TWEED IN THE CENTRE OF THE BERWICKSHIRE MERSE, WHICH IS THE LOWER PLAIN OF THE TWEED VALLEY. THE MERSE ROUND WHITSOME IS COVERED IN LONG, LOW HILLS, UP TO 20M HIGH, MADE OF CLAY, SANDS AND GRAVELS, LEFT BY THE RETREATING ICE AND MELTING WATERS 10,000 YEARS AGO. THESE HILLS ARE CALLED DRUMLINS, AND GIVE A TYPICAL ROLLING LANDSCAPE. THE AREA IS ONE OF THE DRIEST IN SCOTLAND, RAINFALL BEING 650 MM, WITH NOT MUCH WINTER SNOW. THE UNDERLYING ROCKS ARE CARBONIFEROUS SANDSTONE, WITH SOME LIMESTONE, MAKING A VERY RICH, ARABLE AREA OF FARMLAND.
